story:
Toolstation are proud to be partnering with Macmillan Cancer Support for the next two years.

There are currently 3 million people living with cancer in the UK, with someone receiving a cancer diagnosis every two minutes. We know that one in two people in the UK will experience a cancer diagnosis in their lifetime.

For more than 100 years Macmillan has been there for people with cancer when they needed them most.  Today is no exception!

Cancer is not going anywhere.  And neither can Macmillan.

Join us in supporting Macmillan, so they can keep providing physical, financial and emotional support to the millions of people that count on them.

story:
Andy was passionate about St John Ambulance and the first aid courses they provide. St John people make a positive impact every day from responding to emergencies, to supporting communities and saving lives.

First aid volunteers are trained to help those suffering from injury or sudden illness, to alleviate pain and suffering, and occasionally even to save a life. Often proper immediate medical care can make a big difference.

Many of us have witnessed life-saving and crucial help to the injured, provided by trained first aid volunteers. Simply, their presence enables us to hold sporting events such as our orienteering. This training is an essential part of our sport. The support of St John Ambulance would not be possible without charity funding.

Andy's family would be grateful for donations to St John Ambulance. Please donate what you can and add gift aid wherever possible.

Love and best wishes to all.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

During lockdown I decided to set myself a challenge of running 5K every day in November totalling 150K for the month. You will have all heard of guide dogs for the Blind but you may not know that our youngest daughter is on the waiting list for a guide dog and this charity along with most charities have been affected by the lockdown. It currently costs around £63,000 to breed train and support a guide dog from birth to retirement, however, the cost of the guide dog is impacted not just by the cost of breeding and training, but also the cost of all the support functions for the partnership over an average of seven years, as well as external support such as food and vets bills. A guide dog owner may have as many as eight guide dogs in their lifetime bringing the total cost to around £500,000.

This is a small gesture towards a huge costs and although it might be a year or two before our daughter Hadley will benefit from this I do hope you will support the essential and amazing  work that Guide Dogs for the Blind does. Thank you..

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Hi everyone!

This term, all of our charity initiatives will be in aid of the amazing Great Ormond Street Hospital charity!

The hospital has relied on charitable support since it first opened. One of the main sources for this support is Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity. Whilst the NHS meets the day-to-day running costs of the hospital, the fundraising income allows Great Ormond Street Hospital to remain at the forefront of child healthcare.

The charity aims to raise over £50 million every year to complete the next two phases of redevelopment, as well as provide substantially more fundraising directly for research. The charity also purchases up-to-date equipment, and provides accommodation for families and staff.

I am so proud of our Blakely bear & everything he has faced in his first 5 months. Due to complications and abnormalities in pregnancy Blakely stayed in hospital for additional 5 days post birth and since has had 2 ultrasounds on his stomach, 2 echos on his heart, and is awaiting an MRI under sedation. Throughout this he has been the bravest little boy, always smiling to the nurses & laughing all the way through. I have every faith that he is absolutely fine & he is excelling all of his milestones. This year has been such a strange one, but also the best year yet because you arrived <U+0001F499> You have brought so much light, laughter and love into our lives little bear <U+0001F43B> we love you more than you will ever know! Thank you for always being our happy, smiley little soldier no matter what. Mummy’s best friend always <U+0001F90D> During his stay in hospital Blakely was referred to Great Ormond Street Hospital for cardiology & genetics. Although it was a very brief visit with them (thank god!) they really were amazing and really reassured me that he is okay. It really put things into perspective for me that there are so many other little babies that aren’t as lucky as Blakely and have to spend a lot of their time in hospital with conditions that are a lot more serious than his. Next year we will be taking part in ‘Running off Christmas’ where as a family (Blakely in the buggy of course) we will run/jog/walk 31 miles across January to raise money for GOSH. It would mean the world to me if you could donate a small amount to such an amazing charity<U+0001F49B>

story:
Fellow friends and family, I need your help...

My 7 week old Nephew is currently in Great Ormond Street Hospital with a rare form of cancer (30 cases in 15 years) Rory is the most bravest little baby boy I have ever known  and continues to surprise us every day with his strength and determination to fight this. My sister and brother in law have just been amazing throughout, they are so positive and cannot wait to get their little guy home 😃 The staff at GOSH have just been incredible looking after Rory. Their love and support towards my family is just amazing and I will always be forever grateful to them.

Our little fighter 💙

So my turn to do something for them to say thank you...This January, I’m kickstarting 2021 by taking part in Running off Christmas. I will be running 31 miles throughout the month to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children’s Charity. Not many miles I hear you say...well, for anyone that knows me, to run 5k is hard enough so to run 31 miles over the month is BIG!!

It's quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the Give Now button PRETTY PLEASE 🙏🏻😃

Thank you thank you in advance

story:
In what has been a uniquely strange and challenging year, Tony & Keir have decided to try and inject a bit of fun during the month of 'Movember' by challenging each other in a workplace 'Tache-off'. Who will grow the most peculiar or weird looking mouser? Will there be mutton chops involved or inspiration taken from a 1980's styled Tom Selleck?

There is, of course, a serious side to this which is why we are trying to raise a bit money for charity through growing our facial misdemeanours. Movember’s mission is more relevant now than ever. Social isolation has affected the mental health of all of us, including our fathers, partners, brothers, sons and friends. Especially those already finding it hard to stay connected. And its impact will stick around long after the pandemic is over.

Even starting a conversation about the men’s health crisis is valuable. Not everyone knows that, globally, one man dies by suicide every minute of every day. That nearly 10 million men around the world are living with or beyond prostate cancer. Or that testicular cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer in young men.

Although Movember is mainly aimed at raising awareness of men's health, we both wanted to raise donations for a charity that could be of benefit to everyone in terms of impact of funds we raise. That is why we have chosen Cancer Research UK. We will likely have all been affected by cancer in one way or an other during our lives so the hope is that our fundraising can go some way to helping research into the prevention, diagnosis and development of treatments against all forms of this disease.

So if you are able to spare a few pennies in support of the 'Tache-off' and helping Cancer Research UK along the way, then Tony & Keir will be incredibly grateful and will make our facial hair growing worth every itchy minute (with photos and results pending!).

Stay safe everyone.

Tony & Keir

story:
How?

100 kilometres (two and a half marathons) in one go is going to take discipline each day (sleep, diet, training, progress, work/life balance, discipline, focus and prioritisation) until race day, 4th September 2021. 

I have no marathon experience, the furthest I had ever run was a Parkrun before a couple of months ago. This distance isn't particularly recommended for someone with this experience level, so I hope that it's a commitment and challenge really worth supporting!

Not only is the distance "ultra", we will be effectively climbing Snowden twice along the way in terms of elevation gain along Sussex's South Coast.

Follow our story @dadsontherun2021 on Instagram for updates/sadistic amusement/health and fitness info/breakdowns

Why?

Charity:

The World Wide Fund for Nature is an international non-governmental organization founded in 1961 that works in the field of wilderness preservation and the reduction of human impact on the environment.

Supporting organisations of this nature is a key element of fighting climate breakdown and the destruction of natural, local biodiverse habits across the globe.

Climate breakdown is something I really want to support and do better at myself and a challenge like this is part of that process.

Personal:

This is an opportunity for me to reset my own narrative after a long and slow recovery from covid-19. I have already seen real benefits from self care, consistency and positivity. I want to see how much further I can take this, and how much more I can learn. 

Positive psychology and specific purpose really do give balance and security amongst all the trappings and difficulties that modern society poses us all, let alone lockdowns and ambiguous futures. 

I hope the information and motivation my Instagram updates provide can inspire others to do something similar, or something that works for them. 

This is a transformative challenge for me and your support, however big or small, would be greatly appreciated and have a real impact on the WWF AND me adhering to my schedule and routine as I push myself to make this happen.

@dadsontherun2021 Instagram

story:
My name is Helen Everitt. I am a 35yr old mother of 2 beautiful young children, in Devon, UK. 

I recently had ACDF surgery to my spine for a slipped disc at the C6/C7 level. My spinal cord was left damaged, leaving me numb from the stomach down, my left leg immobile and reduced function in my arms and fingers. I then had a spinal fluid leak post-surgery which required another operation to repair it. The doctors estimate I could walk again but it will take time. I am grateful to be alive and that this is no worse. We have been incredibly well looked after and God has proved Himself abundantly faithful. 

I’m going to conservatively estimate the cost of my first surgery alone at £250,000. For one person, one life, in quite drastic circumstances. Meanwhile, every SINGLE day, 800 children die for lack of clean water and soap. It’s so basic and such an easy fix. I would love to try and offset the cost of my surgery by spending the same on sanitation. UNICEF provide soap and clean water access for children in developing countries.


Photo credit: https://bjgp.org/content/bjgp/68/671/296.full.pdf

Because 821 million people around the world are chronically undernourished

Because 3.1 million children die every year from malnutrition

Because every 3.6 secondes one person for of starvation.

Through FAST24, we try to raise funds for these children, whose lives are threatened because of the lack of proper food. In 2017, UNICEF treated more than 4 million children for severe acute malnutrition. Besides, UNICEF on Campus Lancaster university contributed to save 7,595 children and helped in improving their lives!
